contextId.information: "every nation in the world." This is an exaggeration that emphasizes that the people came from many different nations. AT: "many different nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This may be an exaggeration. AT: "almost all of the people who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

This is an exaggeration in order to emphasize the importance of their task of teaching the word of God. AT: "stop preaching and teaching the word of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: give up the word of God

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration. AT: "Many of the Samaritans in the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"They were all" is an exaggeration for many or most of them. AT: "almost all of them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: but they were all afraid of him

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration for Peter's visiting many of the believers throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is a hyperbole meaning "many people who lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is exaggerated to emphasize how widely this was known. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: all the nation of the Jews

contextId.information: This is a hyperbole. AT: "in many places in Judea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This was an exaggeration refering to the Roman Empire. AT: "throughout the Roman Empire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is an exaggeration that emphasizes that many Jews know about Paul. AT: "many Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
